At lower prices it was an intriguing bet for some investment firms because of the riskreward proposition. The technology was known to be superior to any other at the moment, giving them a strong lead on getting there faster than potential competitors. The biggest risk was the possibility that they would run out of money or not acquire capital fast enough to maintain their lead. The earnings call revealed that ASTS already has the funds to advance their operation through to 2026, that they expect their first five commercial satellites to put them at breakeven, and that the next 17 satellites are expected to be ready to launch in the next 57 months. That was fantastic news and alleviated major fears. Without a major setback with these first five satellites they will continue to acquire funding, get there first, and rivals in space communication will be playing catch up for five years. Why do you think it ran up? It still hasnt lost the daily uptrend and it has retained tremendous growth after doubling in value.
They are going to make a fuck ton of money. Thats the outcome I believe in.
Bad earnings report, bad guidance for next Q horrible operating margins, and slowing growth

he have 44k shares at 2USD .... I think you should learn from him instead
Then let me redirect the question to you. Asking you this because you were nice to the other person on this thread who also is new to investing. Thanks in advance...
That was my point lol.

Going to redirect to ChatGPT because it will answer the question in far more detail than I ever could The behavior youre describing aligns with what some people refer to as swing trading, which involves holding a stock for a short period days to weeks to capitalize on expected price movements. Its different from day trading, where traders buy and sell stocks within the same day, often executing multiple trades in a single day. Many retail investors might buy and hold stocks for short or long periods based on their strategy, market outlook, or financial goals. When you see people talking about buying, holding, or selling specific stocks, they could be Day Traders Buying and selling stocks within the same trading day to profit from small price fluctuations. Swing Traders Holding stocks for a few days to weeks, aiming to profit from shortterm market movements. LongTerm Investors Buying and holding stocks for months or years, focusing on the companys growth or dividends rather than shortterm price changes. Your plan to buy a stock and sell it after a couple of weeks fits more with swing trading. Many people engage in this type of trading to get a taste of the market or to try and make shortterm profits. If you proceed, keep in mind the following Transaction Costs Ensure the potential profit is more than the trading fees, if applicable. Tax Implications In a taxable brokerage account, selling a stock within a year could subject you to shortterm capital gains tax, which is typically higher than longterm capital gains tax. Market Risk Stock prices can be unpredictable in the short term, and your expected profit might not materialize. If this approach appeals to you, youre not alonemany people test the waters of the stock market this way.
Awesome, saved me so much time. Thanks
No problem, best of luck!

Interesting how Klarna is shutting down Salesforce and Workday and cutting half their work force because they are implementing a lightweight tech stackâ€¦.Palantir maybe??

Klarna news is big deal.  They no longer need Saleforce or Workday.   AI makes these providers a net loser because their functions can be replaced with AI related functions that are much cheaper.  Klarna cannot be the only one removing CRM. note that WDAY makes almost no money on GAAP basis.  Their so-called Adjusted EPS is "misinformation" because it adds back an enormous amount of stock-based comp.  I do not understand why SBC should be excluded???  If you did not need to pay employees with stock then why pay them - obviously many key employees would leave if you only gave them the current cash comp and eliminated the SBC.  WDAY grows by offering products to make no "real money".  The gig will soon be up for WDAY.

Lots of nervousness as we head into earnings. WDAY needs to pull a maneuver like NOW. Exceed expectations for the quarter by a smidgen (less than 0.5%) and raise guidance by a rounding error amount (less than 0.25%). That still technically qualifies as a "beat & raise" and will position WDAY to ramble on to $250-plus. But if WDAY cuts full-year guidance (even if its by just 1%), say hello to $190/share in the immediate term. Fingers crossed.
